facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 901 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 901 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1039 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 22, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1039 of 1954.

facts.text: Respondents brought suit in court of Second Munsif, Burdwan for declaration of entitlement to property, confirmation of possession, permanent injunction, or delivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents brought a suit in the court of the Second Munsif, Burdwan for a declaration that they were entitled to the property in dispute, for confirmation of their possession thereof and for a permanent injunction restraining the appellant from interfering with their possession. In the alternative they prayed for delivery of possession to them of the property in dispute in case it was found that they were not in possession.

facts.text: Property in dispute belonged to Jatindra Mohan Hajra, father of three of the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the respondents was that the property in dispute belonged to one Jatindra Mohan Hajra, who was the father of three of the respondents.

facts.text: Jatindra Mohan Hajra mortgaged the property to Kali Krishna Chandra.

anchor.surface_text: He mortgaged the property to Kali Krishna Chandra who was a defendant in the suit.

facts.text: Kali Krishna Chandra obtained mortgage decree in Court of Subordinate Judge Burdwan.

anchor.surface_text: Kali Krishna Chandra obtained a mortgage decree in the Court of the Subordinate Judge Burdwan and in execution of the said decree got the mortgaged property sold,

facts.text: Mortgaged property sold in auction sale and Kali Krishna Chandra purchased it and came into possession in November 1937.

anchor.surface_text: purchased the property in auction sale and thus came into possession thereof in November 1937.

facts.text: Auction sale happened before S. 37-A introduced by Bengal Agricultural Debtors Amendment Act, 1942, No. 11 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: This happened before S. 37-A was introduced in the Act by the Bengal Agricultural Debtors Amendment Act, 1942, No. 11 of 1942.

facts.text: Kali Krishna Chandra sold the property to the appellant in June 1942.

anchor.surface_text: the meantime it appears that Kali Krishna Chandra sold the property to the present appellant in June 1942.

facts.text: Respondents applied under S. 37-A and succeeded, obtained possession in November 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After the introduction of S. 37-A in the Act, the respondents applied thereunder for getting back possession of the property. ... The respondents succeeded in their application under s. 37-A of the Act and obtained possession of the property in suit in November 1947.

facts.text: Appellant's interference with respondents' possession led to criminal court proceedings which resulted in acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case further was that their possession was disturbed by the appellant thereafter and they had to go to the criminal court in that connection. But the criminal case resulted in acquittal

facts.text: Munsif decreed the suit holding S. 37-A available against bona fide transferee for value.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsif who tried the suit held that s. 37-A was available against a bona fide transferee for value also. ... Holding that s. 37-A applied to bona fide transferees for value also, the Munsif decreed the suit.

facts.text: Jurisdiction issue not raised before Munsif.

anchor.surface_text: But the question of jurisdiction of the Board on the ground that the amount involved was more than Rs. 5,000 was not raised before the Munsif

facts.text: Subordinate Judge overruled jurisdiction objection holding amount Rs. 4,044/8/- but held S. 37-A not apply to bona fide transferee, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: It was in that appeal that it was urged for the first time that the Board had no jurisdiction inasmuch as the amount involved was over Rs. 5,000. That objection was however over-ruled by the Subordinate Judge on the ground that the amount involved was only Rs. 4,044/8/-. But the Subordinate Judge seems to have held that a bona fide transferee for value cannot be affected by the provisions of s. 37-A. He therefore allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: High Court held Board had jurisdiction as amount Rs. 4,044/8/-, S. 37-A applies to bona fide transferees, allowed appeal, restored Munsif decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court considered the two questions... On the question of jurisdiction the High Court held that the amount of debt involved was only Rs. 4,044/8/- and therefore the Board had jurisdiction. On the question whether bona fide transferees for value were bound, the High Court reversed the view taken by the Subordinate Judge and held that such transferees were also covered by s. 37-A. It therefore allowed the appeal and restored the decree of the Munsif

facts.text: Application under S. 37-A showed decretal dues Rs. 5,841.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged in this connection that the very application made by the respondents under S. 37-A shows that the amount of decretal dues was Rs. 5,841

facts.text: Supreme Court held jurisdiction point should have been raised in trial court (Munsif), not permitted later.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this point as to jurisdiction should have been raised at the earliest possible stage in the Munsifs court and as it was not so raised it should not have been permitted to be raised for the first time in the Sub-ordinate Judges court in appeal.

facts.text: Rule 144 under Act limits Board jurisdiction to Rs. 5,000 max, proviso up to Rs. 25,000 with Collector sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 144, framed under the Act, which relates to jurisdiction of the Board, provides that the maximum amount of the sum total of all debts due from a debtor which can be dealt with under the provisions of Act shall be Rs. 5,000. There is however a proviso to this rule to the effect that with the previous sanction in writing of the Collector, a Board may deal with an application if the sum total of all debts due from the debtors exceeds Rs. 5,000 but does not exceed Rs. 25,000.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected jurisdiction contention as not raised in trial court.

anchor.surface_text: As the point was not taken in the trial court in this case, we are not prepared to go into the question whether the total debt due in the present case was over Rs. 5,000 or not

facts.text: S. 37-A introduced in 1942 for relief where immovable property sold after August 12, 1935 in execution.

anchor.surface_text: Section 37-A was introduced in the Act in 1942 and provided for certain reliefs to an agricultural debtor where any immovable property of such person had been sold after August 12, 1935 in execution of a decree of a civil court

facts.text: Property sold was in possession of decree-holder on or after December 20, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: This provision would suggest that an application under 37-A (1) can be made if the property was in possession of the decree-holder on or after December 20, 1939.

facts.text: Alienation by decree-holder to appellant was after December 20, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The present alienation was by the decree-holder after December 20, 1939 and therefore the appellant cannot say that she is not covered by s. 37-A

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

facts.text: Bengal Agricultural Debtors Act, No. VII of 1936 is an ameliorative measure for relief of indebtedness of agricultural debtors.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt the Act was an ameliorative measure for the relief of indebtedness of agricultural debtors and the preamble of the Act shows that it was passed because it was expedient to provide for the relief of indebtedness of agricultural debtors.

facts.text: High Court ordered parties to bear own costs throughout.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore allowed the appeal and restored the decree of the Munsif but ordered parties to bear their own costs throughout.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural requirement to raise jurisdiction early allows opposing party opportunity to prove Collector sanction under Rule 144 proviso if debt exceeds Rs. 5,000.

holdings.text: As the point was not taken in the trial court in this case, we are not prepared to go into the question whether the total debt due in the present case was over Rs. 5,000 or not. We therefore reject the contention as to jurisdiction on the ground that the point was not taken in the trial court.

holdings.text: The words any person used in s. 37-A(8) are of very wide import and would include even a bona fide transferee for value of the property sold.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of wide language in s.37-A(8) post-sale set aside.

holdings.text: We do not think that the legislature could have intended that the relief under s. 37-A(8) should be given only in this limited class of cases [where decree-holder remains in possession].

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction rejects narrow scope limiting relief to decree-holder possession cases.

holdings.text: Where a sale is set aside, whoever may have purchased the property in the sale whether the decree-holder himself or somebody else-will have to give up possession... Further... if the auction-purchaser... has parted with the property subsequently, that person would be equally liable to ejectment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of setting aside sale under s.37-A(8) voids title of all deriving therefrom, including subsequent transferees.

holdings.text: Decree-holder is defined in s. 37-A(12) as including... any person to whom any interest in the decree or certificate is transferred by assignment in writing or by operation of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory inclusive definition extends to assignees, supporting broad application.

holdings.text: The present alienation was by the decree-holder after December 20, 1939 and therefore the appellant cannot say that she is not covered by s. 37-A.

holdings.text: Reading therefore the wide language used in S. 37-A(8) with s. 37-A(1)(c), it is clear that once the sale is set aside, even alienees from the decree-holder would be liable to be ejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of sub-ss.(8) and (1)(c) confirms coverage of alienees unless specifically excepted.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that persons like the appellant were covered by S. 37-A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the point was not taken in the trial court in this case, we are not prepared to go into the question whether the total debt due in the present case was over Rs. 5,000 or not

edges.explanation: The wide import of 'any person' in s.37-A(8) including bona fide transferees, as held in h3, supports the reference to 'wide language used in S.37-A(8)' in the harmonious construction of h8.

anchor.surface_text: ot therefore be said that when the word decree-holder is used in s.37- A 8 , it is companyfined only to the decree-holder-auction-pur- chaser. There i

edges.explanation: Holding that 'any person' includes even a bona fide transferee for value of the property sold directly addresses applicability of s.37-A to such purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: Now if we read the words of s. 37-A  8 , that provision clearly lays down that any person who is in possession of the property  except an under-riyat under certain conditions  shall be ejected therefrom with effect from that date. The words any person used in s. 37-A 8  are of very wide import
The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

edges.explanation: Legislature not intending relief under s.37-A(8) limited to cases where decree-holder remains in possession supports ascertaining broad legislative intention via harmonious construction in h8.

anchor.surface_text: If the argument for the appellant were to be accepted, the benefit of s. 37- A  8  would only be given in a case where the property sold in execution is purchased by the decree-holder himself and he remains in possession... We do not think that the legislature could have intended that
The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

edges.explanation: Purchasers (including others) must restore possession upon sale set aside, with no express protection for transferees, supports conclusion in h8 that alienees are liable.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this that where a sale is set aside, whoever may have purchased the property in the sale wheather the decree- holder himself or somebody else-will have to give up possession... Further... if the auctionpurchaser... has parted with the property subsequently, that person would be equally liale to ejectment
The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Decree-holder is defined in s. 37-A 12  as under - In this section the expression decree- holder includes the certificate-holder and any person to whom any interest in the decree or certificate is transferred by assignment in writing or by operation of law.
The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The present alienation was by the decree-holder after December 20, 1939 and therefore the appellant cannot say that she is not covered by s. 37-A
The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

edges.explanation: Conclusion via harmonious construction that alienees from decree-holder are liable under s.37-A addresses applicability to bona fide purchasers.

anchor.surface_text: Reading therefore the wide language used in S. 37-A 8  with s. 37-A  1   c , it is clear that once the sale is set aside, even alienees from the decree- holder would be liable to be ejected
The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.

edges.explanation: The holding that persons like the appellant are covered by s.37-A directly addresses whether the section applies to a bona fide purchaser for value from the auction purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that persons like the appellant were covered by S. 37-A of the Act.
The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed.
